title: Worst suburbs to park: car spaces listed for $300k-plus amid parking shortage
text:
Single car spaces in Sydney’s cramped inner suburbs have been selling for the same prices as small homes or multiple luxury cars.

Outrageous sums of more than $300,000 are being sought for the car spaces as a rising number of inner city and eastern suburbs homes hit the market for sale without parking.

Nearly a third of the residential properties for sale in Paddington, Surry Hills, Darlinghurst, Bondi Beach and the Sydney CBD did not include off-street parking, analysis of CoreLogic sales data showed.

MORE: Australia’s priciest home sold for $140m

Why tradies are cranking up prices

It was a similar situation in Zetland, Redfern and Woolloomooloo, where just over a quarter of the homes were selling without parking.

There was an even bigger parking shortage in exclusive Potts Point, where about 60 per cent of apartments offered to market over the past three months came without a permanent car space.

Those who rented car spaces within some of these areas could expect to pay up to $1298 per month, with rents tending to be the priciest in the CBD.

Given the astronimical rents, some commuters preferred to purchase parking outright, while investors are eyeing better yields than money in low interest bank accounts.

A single parking spot in the Mantra building on Bond St in the CBD is for sale at $305,000, the same building where a dual parking spot is listed for $475,000.

A Potts Point car space in the Chimes Building on Macleay St has attracted offers of $280,000 since going up for sale in August through Richardson and Wrench agent Geoff Cox.

This kind of money could purchase a fleet of 10 brand new Toyota Corollas or four luxury Porsche Cayennes.

It would also be enough to buy some small units, including a three-bedroom apartment with double parking in Blue Mountains town Lithgow listed for $259,000, or a two-bedroom unit for over 55s in Penrith listed at $250,000-$270,000.

The Chimes Building parking spot has yet to sell because the owner is alleged to want more than $300,000. It is larger than normal at 26sqm but only enough to fit one car.

The spot is already the most expensive parking spot ever sold in the country, changing hands at auction in 2015 for $264,000.

Two spots in a building further down Macleay St have been listed at $220,000. Another parking spot in the Chimes building was listed for about $210,000.

Laing and Simmons-Potts Point director Nuri Shik has sold multiple parking spots for over $200,000 and said the $475,000 listing was not indicative of prices. “That’s not priced to sell,” he said.

The parking spot has been up for sale for more than five years.

Ray White agent Nick Thompson sold four car spots in Elizabeth Bay earlier this year for about $250,000 each — all in the same building on Onslow Ave — and said he was inundated with inquiries when the spots went up for sale.

“Most of the old Art Deco buildings in the area don’t have parking,” he said, adding that parking spots in the area could typically be rented out for about $60 per week.

“Some residents don’t want to rent,” Mr Thompson said. “They want the security of owning the parking and they know the prices will go up. What’s $250,000 today will be $350,000 in a few years.”
description: Sydney’s notoriously short supply of parking has become so dire in some areas that single car spaces have come up for sale at over $300,000, while rents are as high as $400 per week.
